entities.title: Nicola Amati
entities.description: Nicola Amati, Nicolò Amati or Nicolao Amati was an Italian Master Luthier from Cremona, Italy. Amati is one of the most well known luthier from the Casa Amati. Nicola was the teacher of illustrious Cremonese School luthiers such as Andrea Guarneri and Giovanni Battista Rogeri. While no clear documentation exists for being apprentices in his shop, Amati may have also apprenticed Antonio Stradivari,

heading: Deaths
txt: Ambrose Dixon, English-American soldier (b. 1619)

entities.title: Ambrose Dixon
entities.description: Ambrose Dixon was an early American Quaker pioneer who was born in England and emigrated to the America at an early age where he lived in the Virginia Colony before moving to Maryland.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacques-Bénigne Bossuet, French bishop and theologian (b. 1627)

entities.title: Jacques-Bénigne Bossuet
entities.description: Jacques-Bénigne Lignel Bossuet was a French bishop and theologian, renowned for his sermons and other addresses. He has been considered by many to be one of the most brilliant orators of all time and a masterly French stylist.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Kent, English architect, designed Holkham Hall and Chiswick House (b. 1685)

entities.title: William Kent
entities.description: William Kent was an eminent English architect, landscape architect, painter and furniture designer of the early 18th century. He began his career as a painter, and became Principal Painter in Ordinary or court painter, but his real talent was for design in various media.

entities.title: Holkham Hall
entities.description: Holkham Hall is an 18th-century country house located adjacent to the village of Holkham, Norfolk, England. The house was constructed in the Palladian style for the 1st Earl of Leicester by the architect William Kent, aided by the architect and aristocrat Lord Burlington.

entities.title: Chiswick House
entities.description: Chiswick House is a Palladian villa in Chiswick, in the west of London, England. A "glorious" example of Neo-Palladian architecture in London, the house was built and designed by Richard Boyle, 3rd Earl of Burlington (1694-1753), and completed in 1729. The house and gardens occupy 26.33 hectares ; the gardens were created mainly by architect and landscape designer William Kent. The garden is one o

heading: Deaths
txt: Metastasio, Italian-Austrian poet and composer (b. 1698)

entities.title: Metastasio
entities.description: Pietro Antonio Domenico Trapassi, better known by his pseudonym of Pietro Metastasio, was an Italian poet and librettist, considered the most important writer of opera seria libretti.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlo Antonio Campioni, French-Italian composer (b. 1719)

entities.title: Carlo Antonio Campioni
entities.description: Charles-Antoine Campion, italianized as Carlo Antonio Campioni was an Italian composer who was born in Lorraine. He was a prolific composer and represented a link between Baroque compositional methods and those of the Classical style.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Kaspar Basselet von La Rosée, Bavarian general (b. 1710)

entities.title: Johann Kaspar Basselet von La Rosée
entities.description: Johann Kaspar (Jean-Gaspard) Reichsgraf Basselet von La Rosée was a leading Bavarian general.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Burney, English composer and historian (b. 1726)

entities.title: Charles Burney
entities.description: Charles Burney FRS was an English music historian, composer and musician. He was the father of the writers Frances Burney and Sarah Burney, of the explorer James Burney, and of Charles Burney, a classicist and book donor to the British Museum.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Messier, French astronomer and academic (b. 1730)

entities.title: Charles Messier
entities.description: Charles Messier was a French astronomer. He published an astronomical catalogue consisting of 110 nebulae and faint star clusters, which came to be known as the Messier objects. The purpose of the catalogue was to help astronomical observers distinguish between permanent and transient visually diffuse objects in the sky.

heading: Deaths
txt: Adoniram Judson, American lexicographer and missionary (b. 1788)

entities.title: Adoniram Judson
entities.description: Adoniram Judson, Jr. was an American Congregationalist and later Particular Baptist missionary, who served in Burma for almost forty years. At the age of 25, Adoniram Judson was sent from North America to preach in Burma. His mission and work with Luther Rice led to the formation of the first Baptist association in America to support missionaries.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Hesketh-Fleetwood, English politician, founded Fleetwood (b. 1801)

entities.title: Peter Hesketh-Fleetwood
entities.description: Sir Peter Hesketh-Fleetwood, 1st Baronet, was an English landowner, developer and Member of Parliament, who founded the town of Fleetwood, in Lancashire, England. Born Peter Hesketh, he changed his name by Royal assent to Hesketh-Fleetwood, incorporating the name of his ancestors, and was later created Baronet Fleetwood. Predeceased by an older brother, he inherited estates in west Lancashire in 1

entities.title: Fleetwood
entities.description: Fleetwood is a coastal town in Lancashire, England, at the northwest corner of the Fylde, with a population of 25,939 at the 2011 census.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nikolaos Mantzaros, Greek composer and theorist (b. 1795)

entities.title: Nikolaos Mantzaros
entities.description: Nikolaos Chalikiopoulos Mantzaros was a Greek-Italian composer born in Corfu, major representative and founder of the so-called Ionian School of music.

heading: Deaths
txt: William M. Tweed, American lawyer and politician (b. 1823)

entities.title: William M. Tweed
entities.description: William Magear Tweed, often erroneously referred to as "William Marcy Tweed", and widely known as "Boss" Tweed, was an American politician most notable for being the "boss" of Tammany Hall, the Democratic Party political machine that played a major role in the politics of 19th-century New York City and State. At the height of his influence, Tweed was the third-largest landowner in New York City, a

heading: Deaths
txt: Richard Taylor, American general (b. 1826)

entities.title: Richard Taylor (general)
entities.description: Richard "Dick" Taylor was an American planter, politician, military historian, and Confederate general. Following the outbreak of the American Civil War, Taylor joined the Confederate States Army, serving first as a brigade commander in Virginia, and later as an army commander in the Trans-Mississippi Theater. Taylor commanded the District of West Louisiana and was responsible for successfully opp

heading: Deaths
txt: William Crowther, Dutch-Australian politician, 14th Premier of Tasmania (b. 1817)

entities.title: William Crowther (Australian politician)
entities.description: William Lodewyk Crowther FRCS was an Australian politician, who was Premier of Tasmania from 20 December 1878 to 29 October 1879.

entities.title: Premier of Tasmania
entities.description: The Premier of Tasmania is the head of the executive government in the Australian state of Tasmania. By convention, the leader of the party or political grouping which has majority support in the House of Assembly is invited by the Governor of Tasmania to be Premier and principal adviser.

heading: Deaths
txt: Elzéar-Alexandre Taschereau, Canadian cardinal (b. 1820)

entities.title: Elzéar-Alexandre Taschereau
entities.description: Elzéar-Alexandre Taschereau was a Canadian Cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church. He served as Archbishop of Quebec from 1871 until his death in 1898. The first Canadian cardinal, he was elevated to the College of Cardinals by Pope Leo XIII in 1886.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marie Alfred Cornu, French physicist and academic (b. 1842)

entities.title: Marie Alfred Cornu
entities.description: Marie Alfred Cornu was a French physicist. The French generally refer to him as Alfred Cornu.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mahesh Chandra Nyayratna Bhattacharyya, Indian scholar, academic, and philanthropist (b. 1836)

entities.title: Mahesh Chandra Nyayratna Bhattacharyya
entities.description: Mahamahopadhyay Pandit Mahesh Chandra Nyayratna Bhattacharyya, CIE, was an Indian scholar of Sanskrit, and the principal of the Sanskrit College between 1876 and 1895. A friend and colleague of Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar, he played an important role in the Bengal Renaissance. He was one of the most eminent Bengalis in Kolkata of the nineteenth century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Clara Barton, American nurse and humanitarian, founded the American Red Cross (b. 1821)

entities.title: Clara Barton
entities.description: Clarissa Harlowe Barton was an American nurse who founded the American Red Cross. She was a hospital nurse in the American Civil War, a teacher, and a patent clerk. Since nursing education was not then very formalized and she did not attend nursing school, she provided self-taught nursing care. Barton is noteworthy for doing humanitarian work and civil rights advocacy at a time before women had th

entities.title: American Red Cross
entities.description: The American Red Cross (ARC), also known as The American National Red Cross, is a humanitarian organization that provides emergency assistance, disaster relief, and disaster preparedness education in the United States. It is the designated US affiliate of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and the United States movement to the International Red Cross and Red Cresc

heading: Deaths
txt: Adelbert Ames, American general and politician, 30th Governor of Mississippi (b. 1835)

entities.title: Adelbert Ames
entities.description: Adelbert C. Ames was an American sailor, soldier, and politician who served with distinction as a Union Army general during the American Civil War. A Radical Republican, he was military governor, U.S. Senator, and civilian governor in Reconstruction-era Mississippi. In 1898, he served as a United States Army general during the Spanish–American War. He was the last Republican to serve as the state

entities.title: Governor of Mississippi
entities.description: The governor of Mississippi is the head of the executive branch of Mississippi's state government and the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces. The Governor has a duty to enforce state laws, and the power to either approve or veto bills passed by the Mississippi Legislature, to convene the legislature at any time, and, except in cases of treason or impeachment, to grant pardons and re

heading: Deaths
txt: Abdülhak Hâmid Tarhan, Turkish playwright and poet (b. 1852)

entities.title: Abdülhak Hâmid Tarhan
entities.description: Abdülhak Hâmid Tarhan was an early 20th-century Turkish playwright and poet. He was one of the leading lights of the Turkish Romantic period. He is known in Turkish literature as "Şair-i Azam" and "Dahi-i Azam".

heading: Deaths
txt: Feodor Chaliapin, Russian opera singer (b. 1873)

entities.title: Feodor Chaliapin
entities.description: Feodor Ivanovich Chaliapin was a Russian opera singer. Possessing a deep and expressive bass voice, he enjoyed an important international career at major opera houses and is often credited with establishing the tradition of naturalistic acting in his chosen art form.

heading: Deaths
txt: Viktor Puskar, Estonian colonel (b. 1889)

entities.title: Viktor Puskar
entities.description: Viktor Puskar VR I/1 was an Estonian military commander (Colonel) during the Estonian War of Independence.

heading: Deaths
txt: Franklin D. Roosevelt, American lawyer and politician, 32nd President of the United States (b. 1882)

entities.title: Franklin D. Roosevelt
entities.description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt, often referred to by his initials FDR, was an American politician who served as the 32nd president of the United States from 1933 until his death in 1945. A member of the Democratic Party, he won a record four presidential elections and became a central figure in world events during the first half of the 20th century. Roosevelt directed the federal government during most

entities.title: President of the United States
entities.description: The president of the United States (POTUS) is the head of state and head of government of the United States of America. The president directs the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the United States Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lionel Logue, Australian actor and therapist (b. 1880)

entities.title: Lionel Logue
entities.description: Lionel George Logue, CVO, was an Australian speech and language therapist and amateur stage actor who helped King George VI manage his stammer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ron Flockhart, Scottish racing driver (b. 1923)

entities.title: Ron Flockhart (racing driver)
entities.description: Ron Flockhart was a British racing driver. He participated in 14 World Championship Formula One Grands Prix, achieving one podium finish and won the 24 Hours of Le Mans sportscar race twice.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sydney Allard, English racing driver and founder of the Allard car company (b. 1910)

entities.title: Sydney Allard
entities.description: Sydney Herbert Allard was the founder of the Allard car company and a successful rally driver and hillclimb driver in cars of his own manufacture.

entities.title: Allard Motor Company
entities.description: Allard Motor Company Limited was a London-based low-volume car manufacturer founded in 1945 by Sydney Allard in small premises in Clapham, south-west London. Car manufacture almost ceased within a decade. It produced approximately 1900 cars before it became insolvent and ceased trading in 1958. Before the war, Allard supplied some replicas of a Bugatti-tailed special of his own design from Adlards

heading: Deaths
txt: Heinrich Nordhoff, German engineer (b. 1899)

entities.title: Heinrich Nordhoff
entities.description: Heinz Heinrich Nordhoff was a German engineer who led the Volkswagen company as it was rebuilt after World War II.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ed Lafitte, American baseball player and dentist (b. 1886)

entities.title: Ed Lafitte
entities.description: Edward Francis Lafitte was a pitcher in Major League Baseball who played with the Detroit Tigers (1909–12), Brooklyn Tip-Tops (1914–15), and Buffalo Blues (1915). Born in New Orleans, Louisiana at his family's home located at 319 Bourbon Street, he batted and threw right-handed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Freed, American songwriter and producer (b. 1894)

entities.title: Arthur Freed
entities.description: Arthur Freed was an American lyricist and Hollywood film producer. He won the Academy Award for Best Picture twice, in 1951 for An American in Paris and in 1958 for Gigi. Both films were musicals. In addition, he produced and was also a co-lyricist for the film Singin' in the Rain.

heading: Deaths
txt: Josephine Baker, French actress, activist, and humanitarian (b. 1906)

entities.title: Josephine Baker
entities.description: Josephine Baker was an American-born French entertainer, French Resistance agent, and civil rights activist. Her career was centered primarily in Europe, mostly in her adopted France. She was the first Black woman to star in a major motion picture, the 1927 silent film Siren of the Tropics, directed by Mario Nalpas and Henri Étiévant.

heading: Deaths
txt: Philip K. Wrigley, American businessman, co-founded Lincoln Park Gun Club (b. 1894)

entities.title: Philip K. Wrigley
entities.description: Philip Knight Wrigley, often called P. K. Wrigley, was an American chewing gum manufacturer and executive in Major League Baseball, inheriting both of those roles as the quiet son of his much more flamboyant father, William Wrigley Jr.

entities.title: Lincoln Park Gun Club
entities.description: The Lincoln Park Gun Club was a private gun club founded in 1912 by Oscar F. Mayer, W. C. Peacock, P. K. Wrigley, Sewell Avery, and other prominent Chicagoans. At the clubhouse's dedication, John Philip Sousa directed his band. The club was located in Chicago's Lincoln Park, near Diversey Harbor. The club was built and primarily operated for skeet shooting and trap shooting, with occasional waterf

heading: Deaths
txt: William R. Tolbert, Jr., Liberian politician, 20th President of Liberia (b. 1913)

entities.title: William R. Tolbert, Jr.
entities.description: William Richard Tolbert Jr. was the 20th President of Liberia from 1971 until 1980, when he was killed in a coup d'état led by Samuel Doe.

entities.title: President of Liberia
entities.description: The president of the Republic of Liberia is head of state and government of Liberia. The president serves as the leader of the executive branch and as commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Liberia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Prince Yasuhiko Asaka of Japan (b. 1887)

entities.title: Prince Yasuhiko Asaka
entities.description: General Prince Yasuhiko Asaka  was the founder of a collateral branch of the Japanese imperial family and a career officer in the Imperial Japanese Army. Son-in-law of Emperor Meiji and uncle by marriage of Emperor Hirohito, Prince Asaka was commander of Japanese forces in the final assault on Nanjing, then the capital city of Nationalist China, in December 1937. He is alleged to have been a perpe

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Louis, American boxer and wrestler (b. 1914)

heading: Deaths
txt: Jørgen Juve, Norwegian football player and journalist (b. 1906)

entities.title: Jørgen Juve
entities.description: Jørgen Juve was a Norwegian football player, jurist, journalist and non-fiction writer. He played as a striker for Lyn, and also for the Norway national team. He is the highest scoring player ever for Norway, with 33 goals in just 45 games. He was captain of the Norwegian team which won Olympic bronze medals in the 1936 Summer Olympics. He also had a career as a journalist for Dagbladet and Tidens

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Morton, American baseball player (b. 1944)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edwin T. Layton, American admiral and cryptanalyst (b. 1903)

entities.title: Edwin T. Layton
entities.description: Edwin Thomas Layton was a rear admiral in the United States Navy. Layton is most noted for his work as an intelligence officer before and during World War II.

entities.title: Cryptanalysis
entities.description: Cryptanalysis is the study of analyzing information systems in order to study the hidden aspects of the systems. Cryptanalysis is used to breach cryptographic security systems and gain access to the contents of encrypted messages, even if the cryptographic key is unknown.

heading: Deaths
txt: Valentin Kataev, Russian author and playwright (b. 1897)

entities.title: Valentin Kataev
entities.description: Valentin Petrovich Kataev was a Russian and Soviet novelist and playwright who managed to create penetrating works discussing post-revolutionary social conditions without running afoul of the demands of official Soviet style. heading: Deaths
txt: Colette Deréal, French singer and actress (b. 1927)

entities.title: Colette Deréal
entities.description: Colette Deréal was a French actress and singer.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alan Paton, South African historian and author (b. 1903)

heading: Deaths
txt: Abbie Hoffman, American activist, co-founded Youth International Party (b. 1936)

entities.title: Abbie Hoffman
entities.description: Abbot Howard Hoffman, better known as Abbie Hoffman, was an American political and social activist who co-founded the Youth International Party ("Yippies") and was a member of the Chicago Seven. He was also a leading proponent of the Flower Power movement.

entities.title: Youth International Party
entities.description: The Youth International Party (YIP), whose members were commonly called Yippies, was an American youth-oriented radical and countercultural revolutionary offshoot of the free speech and anti-war movements of the late 1960s. It was founded on December 31, 1967. They employed theatrical gestures to mock the social status quo, such as advancing a pig as a candidate for president of the United States

heading: Deaths
txt: Sugar Ray Robinson, American boxer (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ilario Bandini, Italian racing driver and businessman (b. 1911)

entities.title: Ilario Bandini
entities.description: Ilario Bandini was an Italian businessman, racing driver, and racing car manufacturer.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Wald, American neurologist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1906)

entities.title: George Wald
entities.description: George Wald was an American scientist who studied pigments in the retina. He won a share of the 1967 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine with Haldan Keffer Hartline and Ragnar Granit.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert Ford, Canadian poet and diplomat (b. 1915)

entities.title: Robert Ford (poet)
entities.description: Robert Arthur Douglas Ford, was a Canadian poet, translator and diplomat.

heading: Deaths
txt: Boxcar Willie, American singer-songwriter (b. 1931)

entities.title: Boxcar Willie
entities.description: Lecil Travis Martin, whose stage name was Boxcar Willie, was an American country music singer-songwriter and enlisted United States Air Force Flight Engineer, who sang in the "old-time hobo" music style, complete with dirty face, overalls, and a floppy hat. "Boxcar Willie" was originally a character in a ballad he wrote, but he later adopted it as his own stage name.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harvey Ball, American illustrator, created the smiley (b. 1921)

entities.title: Harvey Ball
entities.description: Harvey Ross Ball was an American commercial artist. He is recognized as the designer of a popular smiley graphic picture, which became an enduring and notable international icon. He never applied for a trademark for the iconic smiley image and only earned $45 for his efforts. Ball later founded the World Smile Foundation in 1999, a non-profit charitable trust that supports children’s causes.

entities.title: Smiley
entities.description: A smiley, sometimes referred to as a smiley face, is a basic ideogram that represents a smiling face. Since the 1950s it has become part of popular culture worldwide, used either as a standalone ideogram, or as a form of communication, such as emoticons. The smiley began as two dots and a line to represent eyes and a mouth. More elaborate designs in the 1950s emerged, with noses, eyebrows, and out

heading: Deaths
txt: George Shevelov, Ukrainian-American linguist and philologist (b. 1908)

entities.title: George Shevelov
entities.description: George Yurii Shevelov also known by his numerous literary pseudonyms Yurii Sherekh, Hryhory Shevchuk, Šerech, Sherekh, Sher; Гр. Ш., Hr. Sh., Ю. Ш., Yu. Sh., etc. was a Ukrainian-American professor, linguist, philologist, essayist, literary historian, and literary critic of German heritage. heading: Deaths
txt: Moran Campbell, Canadian physician and academic, invented the venturi mask (b. 1925)

entities.title: Moran Campbell
entities.description: Edward James Moran Campbell, was a Canadian physician and academic. He was the founding Chair of the Department of Medicine at McMaster Faculty of Health Sciences from 1968 to 1975. He was also the inventor of the Venturi mask.

entities.title: Venturi mask
entities.description: The venturi mask, also known as an air-entrainment mask, is a medical device to deliver a known oxygen concentration to patients on controlled oxygen therapy. The mask was invented by Moran Campbell at McMaster University Medical School as a replacement for intermittent oxygen treatment, a practice he described as "bringing a drowning man to the surface – occasionally".

heading: Deaths
txt: William Sloane Coffin, American minister and activist (b. 1924)

entities.title: William Sloane Coffin
entities.description: William Sloane Coffin Jr. was an American Christian clergyman and long-time peace activist. He was ordained in the Presbyterian Church, and later received ministerial standing in the United Church of Christ. heading: Deaths
txt: Kevin Crease, Australian journalist (b. 1936)

entities.title: Kevin Crease
entities.description: Kevin John Crease was a South Australian television presenter and news presenter. He was most noted for presenting South Australian edition of the Nine Network's National Nine News with Rob Kelvin between 1987 and 2007.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cecilia Colledge, English-American figure skater and coach (b. 1920)

entities.title: Cecilia Colledge
entities.description: Magdalena Cecilia Colledge was a British figure skater. She was the 1936 Olympic silver medalist, the 1937 World Champion, the 1937–1939 European Champion, and a six-time British national champion.

txt: Patrick Hillery, Irish physician and politician, 6th President of Ireland (b. 1923)

entities.title: President of Ireland
entities.description: The President of Ireland is the head of state of the Republic of Ireland and the supreme commander of the Irish Defence Forces.

entities.description: Karim Fakhrawi, also known as Abdulkarim Ali Ahmed Fakhrawi, was the co-founder of Al-Wasat, considered one of the more popular newspapers in Bahrain by winning numerous awards. He died while in the custody due to severe torture according to the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry. heading: Deaths
txt: Mohit Chattopadhyay, Indian poet and playwright (b. 1934)

entities.title: Mohit Chattopadhyay
entities.description: Mohit Chattopadhyaya was a Bengali Indian playwright, screenwriter, dramatist and poet. He was a leading figure in modern Indian drama. Mohit Chottopadhya died on 12 April 2012. He had been suffering from cancer.

Byrne represented the United States nine times in Chess Olympiads from 1952 to 1976 and won seven medals. heading: Deaths
txt: Mohammad Al Gaz, Emirati politician & diplomat (b. 1930)

entities.title: Mohammad Al Gaz
entities.description: Mohammad Abdallah Al Gaz, was a financier, developer, diplomat, central banker and philanthropist in the early years of the United Arab Emirates. A scion of the House of Al-Falasi, Al Gaz became a member of Dubai's first generation of market-making investors and developers in the 1950s through his partnership with Juma al Majid, ranked among the 100 richest Arabs in 2016.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charlie Murphy, American actor and comedian (b. 1959)

entities.title: Charlie Murphy
entities.description: Charles Quinton Murphy was an American actor, comedian, and writer. He was best known as a writer and cast member of the Comedy Central sketch-comedy series Chappelle's Show and as the co-star of the sitcom Black Jesus. He was the older brother of actor and comedian Eddie Murphy.

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Tarvaris D'Andre Jackson was an American football quarterback in the National Football League (NFL). Jackson played college football for Alabama State, after previously representing Arkansas. He played professionally for the Minnesota Vikings, Seattle Seahawks and Buffalo Bills.

txt: Joseph Siravo, American actor and producer (b. 1955)

entities.title: Joseph Siravo
entities.description: Joseph Siravo was an American actor, producer, and educator. He was best known for his work on Broadway in the Tony Award-winning productions of Oslo and The Light in the Piazza and for his roles in film and television, most notably as Johnny Soprano in The Sopranos and Fred Goldman in The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story.
